facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 183 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 183 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal arose from Patna High Court judgment dated January 21, 1957 in Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 21, 1957, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1956,

facts.text: Patna High Court appeal arose from judgment dated January 23, 1956 of the 2nd Assistant Sessions Judge at Darbhanga in Sessions Trial No. 52 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated January 23, 1956, of the Court of the 2nd Assistant Sessions Judge at Darbhanga in Sessions Trial No. 52 of 1955.

facts.text: 22 accused persons including appellant Galfu Sah were tried by Assistant Sessions Judge of Darbhanga for offences under Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Some 22 accused persons, of whom the appellant was one, were tried by the learned Assistant Sessions Judge of Darbhanga for various offences under the Indian Penal Code alleged to have been companymitted by them.

facts.text: Prosecution case: on May 16, 1954, in village Dharhara, Darbhanga district, a mob of 40-50 persons including accused formed unlawful assembly.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that on May 16, 1954, in village Dharhara in the district of Darbbanga a, mob of about 40-50 persons, including the accused persons, formed an unlawful assembly,

facts.text: Common objects of unlawful assembly: dismantle hut of Mst. Rasmani, set fire to it, commit assault if resisted.

anchor.surface_text: the companymon objects of which were  1  to dismantle the hut of one Mst. Rasmani,  2  to set fire to it and  3  to companymit assault, if resisted.

facts.text: Tetar Mian, chaukidar of village Dharhara, arrived at about 10 a.m. on May 16, 1954 to ascertain births and deaths.

anchor.surface_text: One Tetar Mian, who was the chaukidar of village Dharhara, had companye to the village at about 10 a.m. to ascertain births and deaths for the purpose of supplying the said information

facts.text: Chaukidar found mob dismantling hut of Mst. Rasmani, widow of Ganpat.

anchor.surface_text: When this chaukidar reached near the hut of Mst. Rasmani, who was the widow of one Ganpat, he found the mob engaged in dismantling the hut.

facts.text: Chaukidar protested, appellant hit him with lathi on left thigh.

anchor.surface_text: The chaukidar protested. On this, it was alleged, the appellant hit him with a lathi on the left high.

facts.text: Chaukidar raised alarm, Ramji, Nebi and Munga Lal arrived.

anchor.surface_text: The chaukidar then raised an alarm and several other persons came there including Ramji, Nebi and Munga Lal.

facts.text: Appellant ordered Budi to set fire to hut of Mst. Rasmani and assault Ramji and Nebi.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, it was alleged, the appellant ordered another member of the unlawful assembly named Budi to set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani and he further ordered an assault on Ramji and Nebi.

facts.text: Budi set fire to the hut and it was burnt.

anchor.surface_text: Budi, it was alleged, set fire to the hut and the hut was burnt.

facts.text: Sessions Judge found accused formed unlawful assembly armed with weapons with common object to dismantle hut and assault on remonstrance.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge found that all the accused persons before him did form an unlawful assembly and came to the hut of Mst. Rasmani on the date and at the time alleged, armed with weapons, with the companymon object of dismantling the hut and of companymitting an assault on remonstrance.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held offences of rioting and hurt committed in prosecution of common objects.

anchor.surface_text: He held that in prosecution of the aforesaid companymon objects the offences of rioting and hurt etc., were companymitted.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held arson was isolated act of some members, no common object to set fire to hut.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the charge of arson was companycerned, he held that the act of incendiarism was an isolated act of some members of the unlawful assembly, there being numbercommon object of the entire unlawful assembly to set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani.

facts.text: Sessions Judge accepted evidence that appellant ordered Budi to set fire and Budi did so in consequence; convicted appellant under s.436 r/w s.109 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: He accepted the evidence given before him to the effect that the present appellant had given the order to Budi to set fire to the hut and that Budi had set fire to it in companysequence of the abetment. Accordingly, ... the present appellant under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Budi convicted under s.436 IPC by Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Budi was further companyvicted under s. 436, Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: Patna High Court acquitted Budi of charge under s.436 IPC as evidence not satisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judge who heard it found that the evidence against Budi in respect of the allegation that he had set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani was number very satisfactory and he acquitted Budi of the charge under s. 436, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Patna High Court affirmed appellant's conviction under s.436 r/w s.109 IPC, finding he ordered setting fire and hut was set on fire by a member.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the appellant Gallu Sah was companycerned, he held that the evidence satisfactorily established that Gallu Sah had given the order to set fire to the hut and the hut was actually set on fire by one member or another of the unlawful assembly. On this finding, he affirmed the companyviction

facts.text: Sentence of four years rigorous imprisonment imposed on appellant under s.436/109 by Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the sentence being one of four years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal limited to correctness of conviction under s.436 r/w s.109 IPC and propriety of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is limited to a particular question only, namely, companyrectness of the companyviction of the appellant Galfu Sah for an offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, and the propriety of the sentence passed thereunder.

facts.text: Appellant argued evidence same as against Budi, disbelieved for Budi so should be for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: firstly, he has submitted that the evidence on which the companyviction was based is the same evidence which was given against Budi Sah, and if that evidence was disbelieved with regard to Budi Sah, it should number have been believed against the appellant

facts.text: Appellant argued no evidence that fire-setter acted in consequence of appellant's order.

anchor.surface_text: secondly, he has submitted that though he does number wish to companytend that in every case where the principal offender has been acquitted of the offence, a person said to have abetted the companymission of the offence must also be acquitted, there is numberevidence in this particular case that whoever set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in companysequence of the order of the appellant

facts.text: Tetar did not mention in first information that Budi set fire, but mentioned appellant ordered it.

anchor.surface_text: Tetar, it appears, did number mention in his first information that Budi had set fire to the hut, but he did mention that the appellant had given the order to set fire to the hut

facts.text: Similar infirmity in Ramji's evidence regarding Budi but not for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: A similar infirmity was found in the evidence of Ramji who also failed to tell the sub-inspector of police that Budi had set fire to the hut.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 21, 1957, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1956,
This appeal by special leave is limited to a particular question only, namely, correctness of the conviction of the appellant Galfu Sah for an offence

under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, and the propriety of the sentence passed thereunder. The short facts are these. Some 22 accused persons, of whom the appellant was one, were tried by the learned Assistant Sessions Judge of Darbhanga for various offences under the Indian Penal Code alleged to have been committed by them.

anchor.surface_text: Section 107 defines what abetment is. It says- S. 107. A person abets the doing of a thing, who- First.-Instigates any person to do that thing or Secondly.- Engages with one or more other person or persons in any conspiracy for the doing of that thing, if an act or illegal omission takes place in pursuance of that conspiracy, and in order to the doing of that thing or Thirdly.-Intentionally aids, by any act or illegal omission, the doing of that thing.

concepts.interpretation: Abetment by instigation, conspiracy or aiding.

anchor.surface_text: Section 108 is in two parts and explains who is an abettor in two circumstances- 1 when the offence abetted is committed and 2 when an act is committed which would be an offence if committed by a person capable by law of committing an offence with the same intention or knowledge as that of the abettor.

concepts.interpretation: Abettor when offence abetted is committed.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Raja Khan v. Emperor related to a case where one Torap Ali was held to be guilty of cheating... the headnote... said in general terms that where a person is charged with having committed an offence and another is charged with having abetted him in the commission thereof, and the prosecution fails to substantiate the commission of the principal offence, there can be no conviction for abetment.

concepts.interpretation: General rule subject to exceptions where evidence shows offence committed in consequence of abetment despite principal's acquittal.

issues.text: correctness of the conviction of the appellant Galfu Sah for an offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, and the propriety of the sentence passed thereunder

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is limited to a particular question only, namely, correctness of the conviction of the appellant Galfu Sah for an offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, and the propriety of

issues.text: whether the evidence on which the conviction was based is the same evidence which was given against Budi Sah, and if that evidence was disbelieved with regard to Budi Sah, it should not have been believed against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P. K. Chatterjee has appeared on behalf of the appellant and has contested the correctness of the conviction on two grounds firstly, he has submitted that the evidence on which the conviction was based is the same evidence which was given against Budi Sah, and if that evidence was disbelieved with regard to Budi Sah, it should not have been believed against the appellant

issues.text: whether there is evidence in this particular case that whoever set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in consequence of the order of the appellant, assuming that the appellant gave an order to set fire to the hut

anchor.surface_text: secondly, he has submitted that though he does not wish to contend that in every case where the principal offender has been acquitted of the offence, a person said to have abetted the commission of the offence must also be acquitted, there is no evidence in this particular case that whoever set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in consequence of the order of the appellant, assuming that the appellant gave an order to set fire to the hut, and therefore, the conviction of the appellant for abetment is bad in law.

issues.text: whether the person who set fire to the hut did so in consequence of the abetment by instigation of the appellant, even if specific principal Budi is acquitted

anchor.surface_text: Section 108 is in two parts and explains who is an abettor in two circumstances- 1 when the offence abetted is committed and 2 when an act is committed which would be an offence if committed by a person capable by law of committing an offence with the same intention or knowledge as that of the abettor. ... the point taken by learned counsel for the appellant is that when the learned Judge did not accept the evidence of the witnesses that Budi set fire to the hut, there was really no evidence to show that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in consequence of the order given by Gallu Sah.

holdings.text: We see no violation of any rule of law nor even of prudence in the learned Judge accepting the testimony of some of the witnesses against the appellant, though he did not accept that testimony against Budi Sah.

anchor.surface_text: We see no violation of any rule of law nor even of prudence in the learned Judge accepting the testimony of some of the witnesses against the appellant, though he did not accept that testimony against Budi Sah.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Infirmities in witness testimony specific to identifying Budi as arsonist (omissions in first information, no mention to others) absent for appellant's order to set fire, which was consistently mentioned.

holdings.text: It seems to us, on the findings given in the case, that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani must be one of the persons who were members of the unlawful assembly and he must have done so in consequence of the order of the present appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us, on the findings given in the case, that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani must be one of the persons who were members of the unlawful assembly and he must have done so in consequence of the order of the present appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Given findings that appellant ordered arson and hut was set afire by assembly member shortly after, unrealistic to conclude act independent of order.

holdings.text: It is, we think, too unreal to hold that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so irrespective, or independently, of the order given by the present appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is, we think, too unreal to hold that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so irrespective, or independently, of the order given by the present appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical inference from timing and context of mob action post-order makes independence implausible.

holdings.text: As we read the findings of the learned Judge, it seems clear to us that he found that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in consequence of the abetment, namely, the instigation of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: As we read the findings of the learned Judge, it seems clear to us that he found that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in consequence of the abetment, namely, the instigation of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court findings interpreted as establishing causation via instigation under s.107 IPC.

holdings.text: This general statement was considered in a later decision in Umadasi Dasi v. Emperor, and it was pointed out that in the majority of cases the aforesaid general statement might hold good but there are exceptions to the general rule, particularly when there is evidence which satisfactorily establishes that the offence abetted is committed and is committed in consequence of the abetment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Raja Khan general rule (no abetment conviction if principal acquitted) via Umadasi exception where independent evidence of commission in consequence of abetment exists.

holdings.text: We accordingly hold that the conviction of the appellant for the offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, is not bad in law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Abetment by instigation (s.107,108) complete under s.109 as offence committed in consequence by assembly member, despite Budi acquittal; precedents support.

holdings.text: As to the sentence it does not appear to us that it errs on the side of severity.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Four years RI not excessive given offence gravity; appellant already released on bail for other convictions.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the appeal has no merit and must be dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings affirm lower courts on conviction and sentence under s.436/109 IPC.

precedents.cited_proposition: in the majority of cases the general rule [no abetment if principal not proved] might hold good but there are exceptions, particularly when there is evidence which satisfactorily establishes that the offence abetted is committed and is committed in consequence of the abetment
precedents.cited_holding: exceptions to the general rule where evidence shows offence committed in consequence of abetment

anchor.surface_text: We see no violation of any rule of law nor even of prudence in the learned Judge accepting the testimony of some of the witnesses against the appellant, though he did not accept that testimony against Budi Sah.

We accordingly hold that the companyviction of the appellant for the offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, is number bad in law. As to the sentence it does number appear to us that it errs oil the side of severity. It has been stated that the appellant was released on bail on serving out the sentence passed against him for the offences under ss. 147 and 323, Indian Penal Code. In our opinion, the appeal has no merit and must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: As we read the findings of the learned Judge, it seems clear to us that he found that the person who set fire to the hut of Mst. Rasmani did so in consequence of the abetment, namely, the instigation of the appellant.

We accordingly hold that the companyviction of the appellant for the offence under s. 436 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, is number bad in law. As to the sentence it does number appear to us that it errs oil the side of severity. It has been stated that the appellant was released on bail on serving out the sentence passed against him for the offences under ss. 147 and 323, Indian Penal Code. In our opinion, the appeal has no merit and must be dismissed.
